name: Ashwagandha
preparation: Powder with warm milk
safety: Avoid during pregnancy; may cause drowsiness

name: Tulsi (Holy Basil)
preparation: Decoction (Kadha) or fresh leaves
safety: Generally safe; avoid excessive use if trying to conceive

name: Neem
preparation: Paste for external use; juice or tablets internally
safety: Avoid prolonged internal use; contraindicated in pregnancy

name: Brahmi
preparation: Powder with ghee or warm water
safety: May cause mild stomach upset on an empty stomach

name: Amla (Indian Gooseberry)
preparation: Fresh juice or dried powder (Churna)
safety: May increase acidity if taken in excess on an empty stomach

name: Turmeric (Haldi)
preparation: Powder with warm milk (Golden Milk) or in cooking
safety: High doses may cause gastrointestinal upset; caution with blood thinners

name: Giloy (Guduchi)
preparation: Decoction of the stem or fresh juice
safety: May lower blood sugar; diabetics should monitor levels

name: Shatavari
preparation: Powder with milk or ghee
safety: Avoid in cases of severe congestion or estrogen-sensitive conditions

name: Arjuna
preparation: Bark decoction (Kshir Pak) with milk
safety: Consult a doctor if on allopathic heart medications

name: Guggul
preparation: Purified resin tablets
safety: Avoid during pregnancy and if hyperthyroid; may cause mild GI distress

name: Shilajit
preparation: Pea-sized resin dissolved in warm milk or water
safety: Must be purified; avoid in high uric acid conditions

name: Mulethi (Licorice)
preparation: Chew raw sticks or powder with honey
safety: High doses can cause high blood pressure and water retention

name: Haritaki
preparation: Powder with warm water at bedtime
safety: Avoid during pregnancy and extreme dehydration

name: Bibhitaki
preparation: Powder with warm water or honey
safety: Avoid in cases of extreme dryness in the body

name: Aloe Vera (Ghrita Kumari)
preparation: Fresh gel applied topically or juice taken internally
safety: Internal use should be avoided during pregnancy (can stimulate contractions)

name: Ginger (Adrak/Shunthi)
preparation: Fresh juice, tea, or dried powder
safety: May worsen acid reflux or bleeding disorders in high doses

name: Garlic (Lahsun)
preparation: Raw cloves on an empty stomach or infused oil
safety: Can cause bad breath, heartburn; acts as a mild blood thinner

name: Pippali (Long Pepper)
preparation: Powder with honey or in Trikatu blend
safety: Heating nature; avoid in high Pitta (acidity/ulcer) conditions

name: Black Pepper (Kali Mirch)
preparation: Crushed with honey or added to food
safety: Can irritate the stomach lining in high doses

name: Cinnamon (Dalchini)
preparation: Powder in tea or food
safety: Avoid high doses of Cassia cinnamon due to coumarin content

name: Clove (Laung)
preparation: Chew whole clove or apply essential oil locally
safety: Essential oil must be diluted; excessive use can damage gums

name: Cardamom (Elaichi)
preparation: Chew seeds or add powder to tea/desserts
safety: Very safe; excessive amounts may trigger gallstone pain in sensitive individuals

name: Fennel (Saunf)
preparation: Chew seeds after meals or make tea
safety: Generally safe for everyone including children

name: Cumin (Jeera)
preparation: Roasted powder in buttermilk or boiled water
safety: Generally safe in food quantities

name: Coriander (Dhaniya)
preparation: Cold infusion of crushed seeds
safety: Generally safe

name: Fenugreek (Methi)
preparation: Soaked seeds chewed in the morning
safety: May cause diarrhea in large doses; monitor blood sugar if diabetic

name: Ajwain (Carom Seeds)
preparation: Chew with a pinch of black salt or boil in water
safety: Heating nature; may worsen hyperacidity

name: Mint (Pudina)
preparation: Fresh leaf chutney or tea
safety: Can relax the esophageal sphincter, worsening severe GERD

name: Bhringraj
preparation: Infused in oil for scalp, powder for internal use
safety: Cooling nature; use cautiously if prone to severe chills

name: Jatamansi
preparation: Powder or decoction at bedtime
safety: High doses may cause mild nausea or laxative effect

name: Shankhpushpi
preparation: Syrup or powder with milk
safety: Generally very safe, even for children

name: Ashoka
preparation: Bark decoction (Kshir Pak)
safety: Avoid during pregnancy; consult doctor for severe fibroids

name: Manjistha
preparation: Powder with warm water or honey
safety: May turn urine slightly red/orange (harmless)

name: Kutki
preparation: Small pinch of powder with honey or warm water
safety: Very bitter and cooling; avoid in severe diarrhea

name: Kalmegh
preparation: Decoction or tablets
safety: Extremely bitter; may cause vomiting if taken on an empty stomach

name: Punarnava
preparation: Juice of fresh plant or dried powder decoction
safety: Monitor potassium levels if on allopathic diuretics

name: Gokshura
preparation: Powder boiled in water or milk
safety: Avoid in cases of severe dehydration

name: Bael (Bilva)
preparation: Pulp of the raw/ripe fruit or powder of dried fruit
safety: Overconsumption of ripe fruit can cause severe constipation

name: Vasaka (Adhatoda)
preparation: Fresh leaf juice with honey
safety: Avoid during pregnancy (can cause uterine contractions)

name: Bala
preparation: Powder with milk or used as massage oil
safety: Contains mild ephedrine-like alkaloids; use cautiously with high BP

name: Safed Musli
preparation: Powder with warm milk
safety: Heavy to digest; may cause weight gain

name: Kapikacchu (Mucuna)
preparation: Seed powder with warm milk
safety: Contraindicated in schizophrenia; requires medical supervision

name: Vidari Kand
preparation: Tuber powder with milk and ghee
safety: Heavy to digest; avoid if experiencing severe congestion

name: Rasna
preparation: Decoction of the leaves
safety: Generally safe; heating in nature

name: Pushkarmool
preparation: Root powder with honey
safety: Use under supervision if taking allopathic cardiac drugs

name: Kantakari
preparation: Decoction or used in formulations like Dashamoola
safety: Heating nature; use cautiously in high Pitta conditions

name: Varuna
preparation: Bark decoction
safety: Ensure adequate water intake when using

name: Chirayata
preparation: Cold infusion or decoction
safety: Extremely bitter; may cause hypoglycemia in high doses

name: Nutmeg (Jaiphal)
preparation: Tiny pinch of powder in warm milk
safety: Toxic in high doses; strict moderation required

name: Saffron (Kesar)
preparation: 2-3 strands infused in warm milk
safety: Avoid large doses during early pregnancy to prevent uterine stimulation

name: Shallaki (Boswellia)
preparation: Purified resin extract in tablet or powder form
safety: May cause mild gastric irritation; avoid during pregnancy

name: Bhumyamalaki
preparation: Whole plant decoction or powder with water
safety: May lower blood sugar; diabetics should monitor closely

name: Sariva (Indian Sarsaparilla)
preparation: Root infusion or syrup
safety: Generally safe; heavy doses may cause stomach upset

name: Gudmar (Gymnema)
preparation: Leaf powder with water before meals
safety: Can cause hypoglycemia if taken with allopathic diabetes drugs

name: Lodhra
preparation: Bark powder decoction or paste for skin
safety: Avoid in cases of severe constipation due to its astringent nature

name: Khadira (Acacia catechu)
preparation: Heartwood decoction or as a mouthwash
safety: Safe for external and internal use in moderate doses

name: Vacha (Calamus)
preparation: A tiny pinch of root powder with honey
safety: Toxic in high doses; must be purified (Shodhana) before use

name: Chitrak
preparation: Root powder in minimal doses with buttermilk
safety: Extremely heating; strictly avoid in pregnancy and high Pitta

name: Musta (Nutgrass)
preparation: Tuber decoction or powder with warm water
safety: Generally very safe, even for children

name: Daruharidra (Tree Turmeric)
preparation: Stem/bark decoction (Kwath)
safety: Avoid prolonged use; not recommended during pregnancy

name: Shirish
preparation: Bark decoction or seed powder
safety: Safe in moderate doses; use under supervision for chronic allergies

name: Apamarga
preparation: Whole plant decoction or alkaline extract (Kshara)
safety: Alkaline nature can cause irritation; avoid in ulcers

name: Babool
preparation: Bark decoction for gargling or oral intake
safety: High doses may cause constipation

name: Bakuchi
preparation: Purified seed powder internally or oil applied topically
safety: Topical application followed by sun exposure can cause severe blistering

name: Chandan (White Sandalwood)
preparation: Heartwood paste topically or powder infused in water
safety: Extremely safe; avoid adulterated essential oils internally

name: Eranda (Castor)
preparation: Root decoction or purified oil with warm milk
safety: Avoid in pregnancy; overdose causes severe diarrhea and dehydration

name: Hingu (Asafoetida)
preparation: Roasted in ghee and added to food or warm water
safety: Heating nature; avoid in acid reflux or bleeding disorders

name: Jamun (Indian Blackberry)
preparation: Seed powder with warm water before meals
safety: May lower blood sugar too much if combined with insulin

name: Jyotishmati
preparation: Seed oil in drops or seed powder
safety: Highly heating; can cause acidity or restlessness in high doses

name: Kanchanar
preparation: Bark decoction (often with Guggulu)
safety: Avoid in pregnancy; monitor thyroid hormone levels regularly

name: Karanja
preparation: Seed oil applied topically; leaf decoction internally
safety: Seed oil is strictly for external use

name: Karpura (Edible Camphor)
preparation: Micro-doses (must be edible grade) in water or food
safety: Toxic in large doses; strictly avoid synthetic camphor internally

name: Kasni (Chicory)
preparation: Seed or root powder with water
safety: Generally safe; may cause contact dermatitis in sensitive individuals

name: Khus (Vetiver)
preparation: Root infused in drinking water (cold infusion)
safety: Very safe for all age groups

name: Kutaja
preparation: Bark decoction or powder
safety: Prolonged use without active diarrhea can cause severe constipation

name: Lajjalu (Touch-me-not)
preparation: Whole plant paste or powder
safety: Avoid if trying to conceive, historically used as a mild contraceptive in folk medicine

name: Mandukaparni (Gotu Kola)
preparation: Fresh juice or dried powder with water
safety: Safe in recommended doses; rare cases of mild headache reported

name: Nagkesar
preparation: Stamen powder with butter or water
safety: Avoid during early pregnancy unless supervised

name: Nirgundi
preparation: Leaf decoction or infused oil for massage
safety: Heating nature; external use is safer for high Pitta individuals

name: Palasha
preparation: Seed powder with warm water (for worms)
safety: Seeds can be toxic in high doses; requires medical supervision

name: Pashanbhed
preparation: Root decoction
safety: Safe, but must be accompanied by high water intake

name: Raktachandan (Red Sandalwood)
preparation: Heartwood paste applied topically or decoction internally
safety: Safe; internal use should be moderated

name: Saptaparna
preparation: Bark decoction
safety: Strong bitter; may cause nausea on an empty stomach

name: Shalaparni
preparation: Root decoction (often part of Dashamoola)
safety: Generally very safe

name: Tagar (Indian Valerian)
preparation: Root powder at bedtime
safety: Can cause drowsiness; do not mix with alcohol or allopathic sedatives

name: Tamarind (Imli)
preparation: Fruit pulp soaked in water
safety: High acidity can erode tooth enamel and worsen acid reflux

name: Tejpatra (Bay Leaf)
preparation: Powdered leaf in food or as a tea
safety: Generally safe in culinary amounts

name: Trivrit
preparation: Root powder with warm water or milk
safety: Contraindicated in pregnancy, children, and elderly; causes strong bowel movements

name: Vamsha (Bamboo Manna)
preparation: Powder mixed with honey or in formulations like Sitopaladi
safety: Extremely safe for all ages

name: Vidanga
preparation: Berry powder with warm water
safety: Avoid during pregnancy; traditional texts suggest mild contraceptive properties

name: Dhataki
preparation: Dried flowers used in formulations or decoctions
safety: Safe in standard doses; can cause constipation

name: Makoy (Black Nightshade)
preparation: Fresh juice of the whole plant or boiled leaves
safety: Unripe green berries are toxic; only use ripe berries or leaves under supervision

name: Kamala (Lotus)
preparation: Flower petal infusion or seed powder
safety: Very safe and balancing for all doshas

name: Karela (Bitter Gourd)
preparation: Fresh juice on an empty stomach or dried powder
safety: May drop blood sugar excessively if on diabetes meds; avoid large amounts in pregnancy

name: Moringa (Shigru)
preparation: Leaf powder in smoothies/water or drumstick soup
safety: Heating nature; root and bark extracts should be avoided in pregnancy

name: Pippali Mool (Long Pepper Root)
preparation: Root powder boiled with milk at night
safety: Highly heating; avoid in ulcers and severe acidity

name: Priyal (Chironji)
preparation: Seeds eaten raw or ground into a paste with milk
safety: Heavy to digest; overconsumption may cause stomach upset

name: Senna (Swarnapatri)
preparation: Leaf powder or tea infused in hot water
safety: Causes dependency if used daily; can cause severe cramping and electrolyte imbalance

name: Guggulu (Purified Commiphora)
preparation: Purified resin in tablet form
safety: Must be purified; raw Guggul damages kidneys. Avoid in hyperthyroidism.

name: Kupilu (Purified Nux Vomica)
preparation: Strictly processed and purified seeds only
safety: Extremely toxic in raw form; MUST only be prescribed by a certified AYUSH doctor

name: Triphala
preparation: Powder with warm water at bedtime
safety: Safe for regular use; may cause mild loose stools initially

name: Isabgol (Psyllium Husk)
preparation: Husk mixed in warm water or milk
safety: Must be taken with plenty of fluids to avoid choking or bowel obstruction

name: Surana (Elephant Foot Yam)
preparation: Cooked as a vegetable or purified powder (Vati)
safety: Must be properly cooked or purified; raw yam causes severe throat itching

name: Eucalyptus (Nilgiri)
preparation: Essential oil drops in hot water for steam inhalation
safety: Essential oil is strictly for external use/inhalation; highly toxic if ingested

name: Godanti Bhasma
preparation: Purified gypsum ash mixed with honey or ghee
safety: Must be strictly prepared according to Ayurvedic texts; use under medical supervision

name: Curry Leaves (Kadi Patta)
preparation: Chewed fresh, boiled in oil for hair, or added to meals
safety: Generally very safe for everyone in culinary amounts

name: Sarpagandha (Indian Snakeroot)
preparation: Root powder or tablets in prescribed micro-doses
safety: Can cause severe depression or dangerously low BP; requires strict medical supervision

name: Rose (Gulab)
preparation: Petal jam (Gulkand) internally or pure rose water topically/as eye drops
safety: Ensure rose water used for eyes is 100% pure and free from synthetic preservatives
